name: Nuh (Noah)
description: Nuh (Noah) stands as one of the five greatest prophets (Ulul Azm) in Islamic tradition, revered as the 'Second Father of Mankind' who preserved humanity and all living creatures through the Great Flood. His story, detailed extensively in the Quran across multiple surahs, exemplifies extraordinary patience (sabr), unwavering faith (iman), and steadfast obedience to Allah despite nine and a half centuries of rejection by his people. Nuh's mission to call his community to monotheism and his construction of the Ark by divine command represent the archetypal struggle between faith and disbelief, marking a pivotal moment in Islamic sacred history.

origins.propheticLineage: Nuh is the tenth generation descendant of Adam, son of Lamech (Lamak). He was born during an era when humanity had fallen into widespread polytheism and moral corruption, having forgotten the pure monotheism of their forefather Adam.
origins.divineSelection: Allah chose Nuh as His messenger to guide humanity back to the straight path (Sirat al-Mustaqim). He received revelation (wahy) commanding him to warn his people of divine punishment if they did not abandon idol worship.
origins.historicalContext: According to Islamic tradition, Nuh lived for 950 years, spending most of this time calling his people to worship Allah alone. His story is one of the most frequently referenced prophetic narratives in the Quran.

titles: Second Father of Mankind (Abu al-Bashar al-Thani)
One of the Resolute Messengers (Ulul Azm)

mythologicalRole.propheticMission: Nuh was tasked with calling his people to pure monotheism (tawhid) and warning them of divine punishment. Despite 950 years of preaching, only a small number believed, while the majority, including his own son and wife, rejected his message.
mythologicalRole.theArk: By divine command, Nuh constructed the Ark (al-Safinah) on dry land, far from any body of water. Angels assisted in its construction while his people mocked him. The Ark was designed to carry pairs of every animal species and the believing remnant of humanity.
mythologicalRole.theFlood: When the command came, water erupted from the earth and poured from the sky. Nuh called his family to board, but his son Kan'an (or Yam) refused, believing he could survive on a mountain. The flood destroyed all disbelievers while the Ark carried the faithful to safety.
mythologicalRole.newCovenant: After the flood subsided and the Ark came to rest on Mount Judi (in some traditions, the ark landed where the ark rest near modern-day Turkey), Nuh and the survivors established a new human civilization. Allah made a covenant with Nuh, promising never to destroy all of humanity by flood again.

feats: Preached monotheism for 950 years despite constant rejection
Constructed the Ark by divine instruction
Preserved all animal species from extinction
Survived the Great Flood with the believers

quests.name: Building the Ark

quests.name: The Great Deluge
quests.description: Navigating the flood and preserving life on Earth

family.wife: Waila (or Namusa) - disbelieving wife who did not join the Ark
family.believing_wife: Some traditions mention a believing wife who survived

companions.name: The Believers
companions.description: A small group of followers (traditionally 72-80 people) who accepted his message

legacy.quranicSignificance: Nuh's story appears in numerous Quranic surahs, most extensively in Surah Nuh (71) and Surah Hud (11). His narrative serves as a warning to disbelievers and a comfort to the Prophet Muhammad, demonstrating that even the greatest prophets faced rejection.
legacy.theologicalImportance: As one of the Ulul Azm (Prophets of Strong Will), Nuh holds a position of supreme importance in Islamic prophetology. His patience and perseverance are cited as exemplary for all believers facing adversity.
legacy.universalFloodNarrative: The story of Nuh connects Islamic tradition to the broader Abrahamic narrative and resonates with flood myths found across world cultures, affirming the Quran's position on the universality of divine guidance.
legacy.eschatologicalRole: On the Day of Judgment, Nuh will be among the prophets interceding for their communities, and his long life of patience will be weighed among his merits.
